turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: How long you been at it?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Half-hour.  Once I finish this octave I'm gonna get breakfast.  You see what's on the buffet?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: They stopped serving two hours ago.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You haven't seen Susie, have you?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Just wonder what she's up to. I never see her.  Makes me nervous.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yeah, well, she's our girl now.  I think we better keep an eye on her.  There's trouble there.  Hey, listen to this.  Ethel and Bert Lane. Married seventy-five years.  You believe that?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Dedications.  I came up with the idea on the road. See, every morning the maids drop one of these cards in each room.  The guest fills out the card, leaves it at the front desk, and that night we play it.  Daniels went crazy for the idea.  And that's not all.  Last night, after the nine o'clock, he corners me, right, and starts asking about our availability.  Like he wants to line something up. I think he's got a hard-on for Susie.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Thinking there's someone who looks like you, walking around the street somewhere.  Wonder if I saw him I'd think it was you?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: What're you trying to do?  Wake up the whole goddamn hotel?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We were just having a little discussion about morality.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: He's with the hotel.  I called him.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: We had a leak in the bathroom. He fixed it.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: He had to come quickly.  It was a big leak.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: How come I didn't hear anything?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: You're a heavy sleeper, Frank. You've always-been a heavy sleeper.  Unlike me.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: No, you're wrong.  It's just beginning. Come on, have a drink. Show your big brother how it's done.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: A gift.  Courtesy of our courteous hotel manager, Mr. Daniels.  We, dear brother, are a fucking smash.  Yup.  They want us back.  Easter.  It seems they have this egg hunt every year.  Only not for kids. Adults.  They stuff these plastic eggs with Timexes and little certificates for free Mai Tais and everyone has a grand time crawling around on the front lawn.  Then afterwards, they have a dance.  An egg dance.  Everyone comes dressed in a different colored shell and at the end of the evening they crack themselves open.  It's our job to separate the yolks from the whites. Slippery business.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Right.  The Royal.  When's the last time we were there?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Right.  It's incredible how you do that.  Remember things.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Drove me crazy when we were kids. The way you never looked at the music. Miss Simpson would just play it and ...

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Not for me.  I still have to look at the music sometimes, you know that?  Otherwise, I forget. I just forget.  But you.  You never forget. Ever.  So how come you couldn't remember Ma's birthday?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I told you.  It's a useless talent.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: God, the old man would've loved this view, wouldn't he?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I always think of him on New Year's. How he used to pour us each half a can of beer. Remember?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yeah, and you drank yours like it was orange juice. He loved that about you.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It was like you'd passed some test, you know?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: It was just a can of beer, Frank.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yeah, but he told you things.  He never told me anything.  Even though I was the oldest. It was always you two, running off, doing things together.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I could've.  But he didn't want me to.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Maybe so.  You ever go back there?  Where it happened.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: That takes care of this week.  The tenth we got the Sheraton, the sixteenth we're at the Capri.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I mean maybe you should check with us before you go off and book us a month in advance.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I play two hundred nights a year with you, Frank. How much more reasonable you expect me to be?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Just until we find another girl.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You want to know how much I got tied up in deposits with Willie?  We're in for three weeks solid, Jack.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You know, my brother and I have been playing together, gosh, I don't know.  Jack?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I told you, Jack.  It's a telethon. No one gets a cent.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It's a disease, Jack.  We're against it. It's not a moral decision.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: A channel. It's just a little further down the dial, that's all. Look, it's publicity.  Publicity's publicity.  Right?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We're on after Meadowlark.  What's wrong?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Are you kidding me?  Are you fucking kidding me?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: We're playing for a goddamn gymnasium!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: What-are you?  A fucking moron? It's three o'clock in the morning, Frank.  Who's watching?  Your wife? Maybe you can get us a gig playing Little Frank's birthday party. What do you think?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Look.  I didn't know when we were going to be on until yesterday.  What was I supposed to do? I had the pianos anyway.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Basketballs, Frank.  You had us playing for basketballs.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I'm sorry.  I should've checked it out.  I screwed up.  But that doesn't mean you walk out in the middle of a gig.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It wasn't professional, Jack.  It was a stunt. A stupid-ass stunt.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: What's happening to you, Frank?  You been kissing ass so long you're starting to like it?  You let that guy turn us into clowns tonight.  We were always small time, but we were never clowns, Frank. What's happened to your dignity?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Dignity?  Who the hell are you to talk about dignity?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: No, let's stay on it.  I'm sick and tired of watching you make him up into some kinda god. For Christ sake, Jack, he died doing a stupid bullshit jig.  He left a wife and two sons.  He wasn't a hero.  He was a fool.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: That's right.  I wasn't there.  I don't have the luxury of being a witness to tragedy.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: No, fuck you.  And fuck him too. Fuck the both-of you.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I didn't hear you come in.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Oh ... I was just hoping for something to drink.  But it seems the old lady was dry. Not even a bottle of cooking sherry.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Uh, we already boxed some things.  I figured you'd want to go through Dad's stuff.  It's in there. If you want to get started.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Is everything done?  The arrangements, I mean.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Oh. Yeah.  It was all worked out before, you know. She and Dad had taken care of it.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I set it for Wednesday.  The ceremony.  They're doing the stone today.  It's okay?  Wednesday?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: There's not going to be a viewing. I figured with the kids and all ...

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Bought it on the way over.  Clean as a nun.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: No, it's not that.  I ... can't drink from the bottle.  I ... gag.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Hey, what do you know.  Looks like we can have that drink after all.  What's your pleasure?  We got the downtown Ramada. We got the Travelodge on Route 41. And ... the Mallory.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Looks like these got a few years on them.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Oh. Fine.  It was nothing.  Couple sore knuckles.  Nothing.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: You know, that night, I ... It just all came up.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I mean, you can play.  You're okay.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Yeah.  Larry Shelton.  Blackie.  Couple others. Donna said even Lloyd called the other day. Nothing like a little absence to make the heart grow fonder, huh?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Jesus, when was the last time we played the Mallory?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Right.  It was someone's birthday. Halloran?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Christ, that's right.  How could I forget.  What a nightmare.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I told Halloran we didn't do vocals, but he said:

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You should've told us you were coming, Ma. We would've come and got you.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: The audience was a little off tonight.

turns.speaker: MRS.  BAKER
turns.text: A few empty tables.  It's cozier. Besides, Mel Torme couldn't fill this place on a Wednesday night.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I guess you're,right.  Well, what do you say we get a little midnight snack? Theo's should still be open.

turns.speaker: MRS.  BAKER
turns.text: No, no.  You boys are tired.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: A cab?  Ma, come on.  My car's just a half block down.  You wait here.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: So she's got a few sniffles.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You got no right springing this on me, Frankie. It's unethical.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Look, Nick.  You want us to pack up, we'll pack up.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What am I gonna do?  Put a record player out there?  Bad, Frankie.  Bad.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Moran.  Monica.  The whole thing. It's my stage name.  My real name's Blanche.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: No romance, right?  That's why I came up with Monica. It's what I prefer.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: But if you call my house and my mother answers, ask for Blanche.  If you ask for Monica, she'll think you have the wrong number and hang up.

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: And if she asks what it's about, don't tell her. She's opposed to my career.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Uh-huh.  Well, Miss Moran, what is it you'd like to do for us?

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Candy Man.'  Is that all right?

turns.speaker: MONICA
turns.text: Oh, sorry.  I get so caught up in it sometimes.  It's scary.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: This is where the auditions were.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You're an hour and a half late.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Punctuality.  First rule of show business.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Look, miss.  We're tired, you have gum on your lip, and we're going home.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Just like that, huh?  You're not even gonna give me a chance?

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: I don't believe it.  I come all the way down down here, break a heel, and you're not gonna give me a chance because I have gum on my lip and I'm a few minutes late.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You're an hour and a half late.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: So if I'm so 'late how come you're still here?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Catchy.  You have any previous entertainment experience, Miss Diamond?

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: I'm sorry to interrupt, but when I saw you sitting here, I just had to come over.  Florence Simmons.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Uh ... Frank Baker.  This is my brother.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Hey, it's legit.  Strictly dinner and dance.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Okay.  I think that's all we need to know.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Don't leave a girl hanging. Second rule of show business.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: What are we, an orchestra all of a sudden?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: The problem is I can't hear myself sing with all this...  ... music.  You know what I'm saying?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: I mean, you're supposed to be backing me up, right?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: No. We are not supposed to be backing you up.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We're a team.  We work together.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: So work with me, not against me. Okay?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Christ, look at her. You'd think if she was gonna wear her street clothes she'd have enough sense to come in the back.  Good evening, Miss Diamond.  You're late.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: And how come you guys are the only ones with your pictures on the poster?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We'll talk about it later.  Right now, you gotta get changed.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Is there a language problem here?  Your dress. For tonight.  Where is it?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Do I look like I'm naked?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Come on.  We don't have much time.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: If you ask me, this is pretty stupid.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Just look.  What do you wear? A nine?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: My wife wears a seven.  You don't look like a seven to me.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Okay, okay.  Here, how about this?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We're not exactly silly with time, you know.  Jack, you find anything?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Hey, pal.  I don't know about you, but where I come from there's a little girl's room and a little boy's room and the little boys don't go where the little girls go.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: All right, but make it quick.  Shoes!  What size do you wear?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Well, they're aspiring to be sevens.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You can buy new ones tomorrow.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Don't worry.  We'll take it out of your share.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We need scissors over here! Who's got scissors?  Okay, remember.  Jack and I go on first, I do the set-up, then introduce you. And you say ...

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Good evening, ladies and gentlemen. I can't tell you how thrilled I am to be here. It's like a dream come true. And speaking of dreams ...

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Fucking.  She says fucking in front of an entire room of people.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: For Christ sake, I said it, I didn't do it.  Besides, I don't think they were too offended, do you?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We are not a saloon act.  We do not take tips from dirty old men.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: I was gonna split it with you guys.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We do not take tips.  I'll apply this to the cost of the dress.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: The Carlton's a dump.  No cover.  No minimum. And they water their drinks. It's strictly for the Fuller brush crowd.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I guess it's,the Plaza then. That brings us to the twenty-seventh. We got the Avedon for three or the Park downtown for two.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: We take the Avedon, right?  Simple.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: By the way, I got a messsage yesterday from some guy looking for New Year's action.  Resort, upstate.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Uh, well ... we flipped a coin.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: So find a dime.  Let's get out of here.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Well, well.  Ho, ho, ho.  You moonlighting at Macy's, Frank?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: For the kids.  Merry Christmas, you two.  Don't forget.  We leave the twenty-sixth.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Maybe we should just listen to the radio.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Jesus, you fellas've made a lot of noise.  What's with the stars?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: First times. Hey, look at this.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: He's always right.  Go ahead.  Pick a virgin.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I told you, he's got the gift.  Same with music. Hears it once and he's got it.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: And how about this air? I'm telling you, a few days in this place'll put five years on your life.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Of course it smells like fish. We're on the ocean. What'd you expect, Chanel number five?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Smells like tuna number two to me.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It's paradise.  That's what it is. Paradise.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: As Charlie Steinway is my witness.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: People.' You think Streisand, right? Hot that night.  Chills. Through the whole audience.  I could hardly play.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Wow. You ever see her again?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: No. We got a picture, though. One of the waitresses had a camera.  God, we were just kids.  That was something, wasn't it?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Hey, will you look at that?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: They must've bought the same map we did.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What do you say we send a bottle over?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: I don't believe it.  You're a romantic, Frank.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: He's just afraid to show it. Aren't you, little brother?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Jack woke up on the wrong side of the bottle.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Uh, well, I love you, too, Jack.  So. Susie.  How 'bout it.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Oh. Yeah.  I gotta bunch of them.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Someone needs to grow up.  I won't take it, Jack.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You want to tell me what the hell's going on?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I just saw a man walk out of your room.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: In case you've forgotten, we're being paid to be here.  So it might be nice if you conducted yourself with a certain amount of decency.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: No. You listen.  I had my doubts about you from the beginning

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I just saw a man walk out of your room!

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I guess I ... If I jumped to...

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: How about you?  Got a Bar Mitzvah this weekend?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: That song.  I can't sing it anymore. I'm gonna get sick.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What're you talking about?  They love it.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: I'm gonna throw up, Frank.  I mean it. Let's drop it for the ten o'clock, okay?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Susie.  It's one more show.  One more time.  That's all.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: And two more times tomorrow night, and two more times the next night, and the next night and the next night and the next night.  Frank, I can't sing that fucking song anymore!

turns.speaker: MR. DANIELS
turns.text: Good morning, gentlemen.  I'm Mr. Daniels, the manager.  I believe I've spoken to one of you on the phone.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: That'd be me, sir.  Frank Baker. This is my brother Jack.

turns.speaker: MR. DANIELS
turns.text: Tom here tells me there's a problem with the pianos.  We were assured they were in tune.

turns.speaker: MR. DANIELS
turns.text: Then I'm afraid I don't understand.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: They are in tune.  But not with each other.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Yes, sir.  You're just what we needed on a night like this.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Uh ... You don't know when you'll be wanting us back, do you, Lloyd?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Uh, well, you know, the way our schedule is, I thought maybe...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Yes, sir.  That's quite a girl you boys latched onto.  She a local?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Lucky for you.  Well, there you go, guys. Don't spend it all in one place. Oh ... you want to count it, Jack?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We trust you, Lloyd.  You know that.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Shit, thank God.  You look like a creep.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: I mean, I'd hate to think I'd pick up someone who wore that shit.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: So. I'm here, you're here, the piano's here.  What d'ya say?

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: You know, I'm feeling a lot of hostility from you.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: You should've brought a leash, Mr. Barker. The doctor doesn't like to be bitten.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: No, I, uh, left a dog here this morning. He needed some work on his mouth.

turns.speaker: KID
turns.text: Regular hours are eight to five.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Yeah, yeah, I know.  I was just passing by. Thought I'd check in on him.

turns.speaker: KID
turns.text: You can check in on him tomorrow. Between eight and five.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Yeah, well, couldn't I take a look now?

turns.speaker: KID
turns.text: You want to know if he's okay. Right?

turns.speaker: KID
turns.text: Save it.  What's he look like?

turns.speaker: KID
turns.text: All right. they lay the dead ones out in the cold room.  I'll take a look.
